claim: If your income increases and you're bumped up to a higher tax bracket in the U.S., your take-home earnings will still increase overall.

supporting.text: The U.S. federal income tax system is progressive, meaning higher income levels are taxed at higher rates only on the portion of income that falls within each bracket.

attacks.text: The U.S. federal income tax system is progressive, meaning higher income levels are taxed at higher rates only on the portion of income that falls within each bracket.
Some taxpayers may face phase-outs of deductions or credits when their income increases, effectively increasing their marginal tax rate beyond the bracket rate.
Phase-outs typically affect only specific deductions or credits and do not negate the overall progressive nature of the tax system.
State and local taxes may have different bracket structures that could result in a higher overall marginal rate when combined with federal taxes.
Most state income tax systems are also progressive, and the combined effect still preserves the principle that only the marginal income is taxed at higher rates.

supporting.text: Moving to a higher tax bracket does not result in all income being taxed at the higher rate, only the amount exceeding the previous bracket's threshold.

attacks.text: Moving to a higher tax bracket does not result in all income being taxed at the higher rate, only the amount exceeding the previous bracket's threshold.
While only the income above the threshold is taxed at the higher rate, other factors like state taxes, deductions, or phase-outs of credits may reduce take-home earnings.
State taxes and deductions are separate from federal tax brackets and do not negate the fact that take-home earnings still increase when moving to a higher federal tax bracket.
In rare cases, crossing into a higher tax bracket may disqualify individuals from certain tax credits or benefits, effectively reducing net income.
Most tax credits and benefits have gradual phase-outs rather than sudden disqualifications, minimizing the impact on take-home earnings.

supporting.text: Take-home pay increases with higher gross income because the additional earnings are only partially offset by the higher marginal tax rate on the incremental income.

attacks.text: Take-home pay increases with higher gross income because the additional earnings are only partially offset by the higher marginal tax rate on the incremental income.
If the higher tax bracket includes significant phase-outs of deductions or credits, the effective marginal tax rate could exceed 100%, reducing take-home pay despite higher gross income.
Phase-outs of deductions or credits are rare and typically affect only very high-income earners, so the scenario in B1 is not applicable to most taxpayers.
State and local taxes may also increase in higher brackets, further reducing the net benefit of additional income.
Most state and local tax systems are progressive but have lower rates than federal taxes, so the combined marginal rate still leaves take-home pay higher.

supporting.text: Standard deductions and tax credits remain applicable regardless of tax bracket, preserving some of the increased income as take-home pay.

attacks.text: Standard deductions and tax credits remain applicable regardless of tax bracket, preserving some of the increased income as take-home pay.
Marginal tax rates mean only the portion of income above the bracket threshold is taxed at the higher rate, ensuring the majority of earnings remain unaffected.
Some tax credits phase out at higher income levels, reducing their benefit and potentially offsetting part of the increased take-home pay.
Even with phase-outs, the progressive tax system ensures that take-home pay still increases, just at a slower rate.

supporting.text: Even with higher marginal rates, the net effect of increased income is a higher absolute amount of after-tax earnings.

attacks.text: Even with higher marginal rates, the net effect of increased income is a higher absolute amount of after-tax earnings.
If the increased income pushes someone into a higher tax bracket, the additional income may be subject to significantly higher marginal rates, reducing the net gain.
The U.S. tax system is progressive but marginal, meaning only the income above the bracket threshold is taxed at the higher rate, ensuring the overall take-home pay still increases.
Certain phase-outs of deductions or credits tied to income thresholds could indirectly reduce net earnings despite the marginal tax structure.
Phase-outs are gradual and affect only specific tax benefits, so their impact on overall take-home pay is usually minimal compared to the income increase.
